fibers out so that caused an outage now if the human factor wasn't involved there would
those servers still be online of course they would okay so let's talk about some key terms
when it comes to disaster recovery and this has nothing to do with aws well it does have everything to do with aws but
these terms have been around long before aws so recovery time objective recovery time objective is the time the
system can be down before you suffer a significant impact so the time or the tolerance that
you can not have access to that system and we call that rto rpo or recovery point objective is the
amount of data that you can afford to lose okay so recovery time objective is in minutes hours days
recovery point objective is generally in minutes hours days of data being replicated to a database for
example or amount of files that you've lost if a hard drive dies so these two terms are very important
rto and rpo now the third factor that really comes into play
when it comes to disaster recovery and planning for disaster or planning your disaster recovery plan
is money okay so dollars are the third factor and if you spend more money you can
decrease your time of the the time of the outage and the amount of data lost
and if you decrease or you don't want to spend as much obviously your time to recover your rto and your data loss is
going to increase so it depends on how much you're willing to spend on your disaster recovery
data center or your dr plan okay so let's talk about conventional
disaster recovery sites traditionally they're high cost and low return on investment so what does that
mean high cost if you have a data center that you've deployed it's cost five million dollars or four million dollars for
example if you want a secondary data center that mirrors that exact workload you need to
spend another four million dollars or another five million dollars okay so you're spending twice the capital expenditure
how often do you actually use that secondary site ten percent of the time five percent of the time never
it's a pretty bad return on investment and usually because of this it's only
implemented for the most critical systems okay so if you're looking at your
critical data that's very important to your business you're generally going to back that up okay you're not going to back up your
payroll on a on a minutely basis okay you're probably going to do that on a daily basis okay and
usually because of the cost of a secondary site in in a dr scenario
the sites are generally scaled down to 50 percent of the full capacity of the primary site
now what's the reason behind that well basically businesses feel like they can still operate at a reduced rate
okay a complete outage may not be acceptable but operating at 50 percent of their their capacity might be acceptable until
they can get the primary site back up and working again that's still two million dollars on a four million dollar investment if your
primary is four million you're spending two million on your secondary also software licenses you pay for
